description: Learn how to access, change, and update the HTML Document Object Model (DOM) using JavaScript.

slides.title: What is the DOM?
slides.content:
# The Document Object Model üå≥

The DOM is a tree structure representation of your HTML.

JavaScript can access the DOM to:
- Change all HTML elements
- Change HTML attributes
- Change CSS styles
- Remove existing elements
- Add new elements

slides.title: Selecting Elements
slides.content:
# Finding Elements üîé

How to grab an element to work with:

- `document.getElementById("id")`: Best performance.
- `document.getElementsByClassName("class")`
- `document.getElementsByTagName("tag")`
- `document.querySelector(".class")`: Returns the **first** match.
- `document.querySelectorAll("div")`: Returns **all** matches (as a NodeList).

slides.title: Changing HTML Content
slides.content:
# Changing Content üìù

The easiest way to modify the content of an HTML element is by using the `innerHTML` or `innerText` property.

```javascript
document.getElementById("p1").innerHTML = "New text!";
```

- `innerHTML`: Parses HTML tags (can lead to XSS if user input involved).
- `innerText`: Better for plain text (ignores hidden elements).
- `textContent`: Raw text content.

slides.title: Changing CSS Styles
slides.content:
# Changing Styles üé®

You can change CSS styles directly via the `.style` property.

Note: Use camelCase for property names (`backgroundColor` instead of `background-color`).

```javascript
document.getElementById("p2").style.color = "blue";
document.getElementById("p2").style.fontSize = "20px";
```

Navigating between nodes.

- `nextElementSibling`

```javascript
const parent = document.getElementById("child").parentNode;
```

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: DOM üéì

Control the page structure.

- **Select:** `getElementById`, `querySelector`.
- **Modify:** `innerHTML`, `style`, `setAttribute`.
- **Classes:** `classList.add/remove/toggle`.
- **Structure:** `createElement`, `appendChild`, `remove`.
